sections.title: Use Restrictions - Residential Use
sections.content: All Lots shall be used exclusively for residential purposes. No trade, business, profession, or commercial activity of any kind shall be conducted on any Lot, except that an Owner or occupant may conduct business activities within the dwelling so long as: (a) the existence or operation of the business activity is not apparent or detectable by sight, sound, or smell from outside the dwelling; (b) the business activity does not involve regular visitation of the Lot by clients, customers, suppliers, or employees; (c) the business activity does not increase traffic or parking in the community; and (d) the business activity is consistent with the residential character of the community and does not constitute a nuisance.
sections.plain_language: Your home must be used as a residence. You can work from home as long as it doesn't look like a business from outside, you don't have regular business visitors, and it doesn't create extra traffic or noise.

sections.title: Use Restrictions - Prohibited Activities
sections.content: No noxious or offensive activity shall be carried on upon any Lot, nor shall anything be done thereon which may be or become an annoyance or nuisance to the neighborhood. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the following activities are expressly prohibited: (a) storage of junk, inoperable vehicles, or unsightly materials visible from neighboring properties or Common Areas; (b) repair or restoration of motor vehicles, boats, or other vehicles, except for minor maintenance within an enclosed garage; (c) discharge of firearms, except by licensed security personnel; (d) keeping of livestock, poultry, or farm animals; (e) operation of machinery or equipment that creates unreasonable noise, vibration, or interference with radio or television reception.
sections.plain_language: Don't do anything that bothers your neighbors. Specifically: no junk or broken cars visible outside, no working on vehicles except minor stuff in your garage, no shooting guns, no farm animals like chickens or goats, and no loud machinery.

sections.title: Architectural Control - General Requirements
sections.content: No building, fence, wall, swimming pool, spa, or other structure shall be commenced, erected, placed, or maintained upon any Lot, nor shall any exterior addition to or change or alteration therein be made, including but not limited to painting, changes in landscaping, installation of solar panels, satellite dishes, or exterior lighting, until the plans and specifications showing the nature, kind, shape, height, materials, color, and location of the same shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Architectural Review Committee (ARC). The ARC shall have thirty (30) days from receipt of a complete application to approve or deny the request. Failure to respond within thirty (30) days shall be deemed approval.
sections.plain_language: You need written approval from the Architectural Review Committee (ARC) before making ANY exterior changes to your property. This includes fences, paint, landscaping, solar panels, satellite dishes, and outdoor lighting. Submit your application and they have 30 days to respond.

sections.title: Architectural Control - Approved Materials and Colors
sections.content: All exterior paint colors, siding materials, roofing materials, and fencing materials must be selected from the Association-approved palette and materials list, copies of which are available from the management office and on the community website. Deviation from approved colors or materials requires specific written approval from the ARC.
sections.plain_language: You must choose from pre-approved colors and materials for any exterior work. Get the approved list from the management office or website.

sections.title: Architectural Control - Fences
sections.content: Fences may be erected on Lots only with prior written approval of the ARC. All fences shall comply with the following requirements: (a) maximum height of six (6) feet for rear and side yard fences, and four (4) feet for front yard fences where permitted; (b) fences must be constructed of wood, vinyl, or wrought iron only—chain link, wire mesh, and barbed wire are prohibited; (c) fence color must be selected from the approved palette; (d) front yard fences are generally prohibited except for decorative wrought iron fencing not exceeding four (4) feet in height; (e) all fences must be maintained in good condition and repair.
sections.plain_language: Fences need ARC approval. Back/side fences can be up to 6 feet tall, front fences up to 4 feet. Only wood, vinyl, or wrought iron allowed—no chain link. Must use approved colors and keep it maintained.

sections.title: Architectural Control - Landscaping
sections.content: All landscaping changes visible from neighboring properties or Common Areas require ARC approval. Front yard landscaping must include at least fifty percent (50%) living plant material. Artificial turf is permitted in rear yards only with ARC approval and must be of high quality, realistic appearance. Xeriscaping and drought-tolerant landscaping are encouraged but must be approved by the ARC to ensure aesthetic compatibility. Tree removal requires ARC approval except for dead, diseased, or hazardous trees, which should be reported to management.
sections.plain_language: Landscaping changes need ARC approval. Front yards need at least 50% real plants. Artificial turf only in backyards with approval. Drought-friendly landscaping is encouraged but needs approval. Don't remove trees without permission unless they're dead or dangerous.

sections.title: Architectural Control - Solar Panels
sections.content: Solar panels and solar energy devices are permitted subject to ARC review and approval. Applications must include detailed plans showing panel placement, dimensions, and mounting system. The ARC may not unreasonably deny applications but may require modifications to minimize visual impact from street view where technically feasible without significantly reducing system efficiency or increasing cost by more than ten percent (10%). Ground-mounted systems require additional approval and screening.
sections.plain_language: Solar panels are allowed but need ARC approval. They can suggest changes to reduce how visible panels are from the street, but they can't make you do anything that reduces efficiency a lot or costs more than 10% extra. Ground-mounted panels need extra approval.

sections.title: Architectural Control - Satellite Dishes and Antennas
sections.content: Satellite dishes one meter (39.37 inches) or less in diameter and television antennas designed to receive video programming are permitted without ARC approval, provided they are installed in a location not visible from the street where reception is not substantially degraded. Dishes or antennas that must be visible from the street due to reception requirements should be installed in the least obtrusive location possible. Dishes larger than one meter require ARC approval.
sections.plain_language: Small satellite dishes (under 39 inches) don't need approval if you can put them where they're not visible from the street. If you can only get signal from a visible spot, put it in the least obvious place. Larger dishes need ARC approval.

sections.title: Architectural Control - Holiday Decorations
sections.content: Holiday decorations may be displayed without ARC approval subject to the following limitations: (a) decorations may be installed no earlier than thirty (30) days before the holiday and must be removed within fifteen (15) days after the holiday; (b) decorations must not create a safety hazard, fire risk, or nuisance; (c) lighting displays must not unreasonably disturb neighbors through excessive brightness or flashing; (d) decorations must not damage Common Areas or community landscaping.
sections.plain_language: Holiday decorations are fine without approval. Put them up no more than 30 days before the holiday and take them down within 15 days after. Don't create safety hazards or blind your neighbors with super bright lights.

sections.title: Maintenance - Owner Responsibilities
sections.content: Each Owner shall be responsible for maintaining their Lot and all improvements thereon in good condition and repair, including but not limited to: (a) exterior surfaces of all structures, including painting, repairs, and cleaning; (b) all landscaping, including lawns, plants, trees, and irrigation systems; (c) driveways, walkways, and patios; (d) fences and walls; (e) exterior lighting fixtures; (f) mailboxes and address numbers. Lawns must be mowed regularly and maintained at a height not exceeding four (4) inches. Dead plants must be replaced within sixty (60) days.
sections.plain_language: You're responsible for maintaining your property including: painting, repairs, landscaping, driveway, fences, lights, and mailbox. Keep your lawn under 4 inches tall and replace dead plants within 60 days.

sections.title: Maintenance - Association Responsibilities
sections.content: The Association shall be responsible for maintaining the Common Areas and the following elements: (a) all Common Area landscaping, irrigation, and lighting; (b) community amenities including the pool, clubhouse, and fitness center; (c) community entrance features and signage; (d) private streets and sidewalks within the community; (e) perimeter walls and fencing; (f) storm water management facilities. The Association is not responsible for maintenance of individual Lots or any improvements thereon.
sections.plain_language: The HOA takes care of: common areas, community landscaping, the pool, clubhouse, fitness center, entrance signs, community streets/sidewalks, perimeter walls, and drainage. They don't maintain your personal property.

sections.title: Leasing and Rentals - General Requirements
sections.content: Owners may lease their Lots subject to the following conditions: (a) all leases must be for the entire dwelling and for a minimum term of twelve (12) months; (b) short-term rentals, including vacation rentals and rentals through platforms such as Airbnb, VRBO, or similar services, are prohibited; (c) subleasing is prohibited; (d) the Owner must provide the Association with a copy of the lease agreement and tenant contact information within ten (10) days of lease execution; (e) the Owner remains responsible for all tenant violations of the CC&Rs and community rules; (f) no more than twenty-five percent (25%) of units in the community may be leased at any time.
sections.plain_language: You can rent out your home, but: leases must be at least 12 months (no Airbnb or short-term rentals), no subleasing, you must give the HOA a copy of your lease and tenant info, you're responsible if your tenant breaks the rules, and there's a 25% cap on rentals in the community.

sections.title: Vehicles and Parking - Assigned Parking
sections.content: Each Lot is entitled to use of designated parking spaces as follows: single-family homes - two (2) garage spaces and two (2) driveway spaces; townhomes - two (2) garage spaces. All vehicles must be parked within designated spaces. Garage spaces must be maintained clear and available for vehicle parking—garages may not be converted to living space or used primarily for storage such that vehicles cannot be parked therein.
sections.plain_language: Single-family homes get 2 garage spaces plus 2 driveway spaces. Townhomes get 2 garage spaces. Keep your garage clear enough to actually park cars in it—you can't convert it to a room or fill it so full of stuff that cars don't fit.

sections.title: Vehicles and Parking - Guest Parking
sections.content: Guest parking is available in designated guest parking areas throughout the community on a first-come, first-served basis. Guest parking spaces are limited to seventy-two (72) hours of continuous use. Residents may not use guest parking spaces for their own vehicles. Guests requiring parking beyond seventy-two (72) hours must obtain a temporary parking permit from the management office.
sections.plain_language: Guests can park in the designated guest spots for up to 72 hours. Residents can't use guest parking for their own cars. If your guest needs to stay longer than 72 hours, get a temporary permit from the office.

sections.title: Vehicles and Parking - Prohibited Vehicles
sections.content: The following vehicles may not be parked, stored, or kept on any Lot or Common Area except within an enclosed garage: (a) recreational vehicles, motor homes, campers, and trailers; (b) boats and personal watercraft; (c) commercial vehicles exceeding 10,000 pounds GVWR or displaying commercial signage visible from outside the vehicle; (d) inoperable vehicles or vehicles without current registration; (e) vehicles leaking fluids onto pavement. Motorcycles, golf carts, and standard pickup trucks used for personal transportation are permitted.
sections.plain_language: The following can only be kept in a closed garage (not visible): RVs, campers, trailers, boats, large commercial vehicles, and vehicles with visible company logos. Broken or unregistered cars aren't allowed. Regular motorcycles and pickup trucks are fine.

sections.title: Vehicles and Parking - Street Parking
sections.content: Parking on community streets is prohibited between the hours of 11:00 PM and 6:00 AM except in designated overnight parking areas. Daytime street parking is permitted but vehicles may not be parked in the same location for more than forty-eight (48) consecutive hours. Fire lanes must remain clear at all times. The Association reserves the right to tow vehicles in violation at the owner's expense.
sections.plain_language: No street parking overnight (11 PM - 6 AM) unless in designated areas. During the day, you can street park but not in the same spot for more than 48 hours. Never block fire lanes. Illegally parked cars can be towed at your expense.

sections.title: Pets - General Policy
sections.content: Residents may keep common household pets subject to the following limitations: (a) maximum of three (3) pets per household, with no more than two (2) dogs; (b) dogs must not exceed sixty (60) pounds at maturity; (c) pets must be registered with the Association within thirty (30) days of acquisition or move-in; (d) a refundable pet deposit of three hundred fifty dollars ($350) per pet is required; (e) all pets must be kept under the owner's control at all times; (f) pet owners are responsible for immediate cleanup of all pet waste; (g) pets creating a nuisance through excessive noise, aggressive behavior, or property damage may be required to be removed from the community.
sections.plain_language: You can have up to 3 pets total, but max 2 dogs. Dogs must be under 60 lbs when fully grown. Register your pets within 30 days and pay a $350 deposit per pet (refundable). Always control your pets, clean up after them, and don't let them be a nuisance.

sections.title: Pets - Breed Restrictions
sections.content: The following dog breeds and their mixes are prohibited due to insurance liability concerns: Pit Bull Terriers (including American Pit Bull Terrier, American Staffordshire Terrier, and Staffordshire Bull Terrier), Rottweilers, Doberman Pinschers, German Shepherds, Chow Chows, Presa Canarios, Akitas, and Wolf Hybrids. Residents with existing restricted breeds as of the adoption of this amendment may keep their current pet but may not acquire additional restricted breeds.
sections.plain_language: These dog breeds are not allowed: Pit Bulls, Rottweilers, Dobermans, German Shepherds, Chow Chows, Presa Canarios, Akitas, and Wolf Hybrids (or mixes of these). If you already had one of these breeds before this rule, you can keep it but can't get another.

sections.title: Pets - Leash Requirements
sections.content: All dogs must be kept on a leash not exceeding six (6) feet in length when outside the owner's Lot, including all Common Areas, streets, and sidewalks within the community. The designated dog park is the only area where dogs may be off-leash, and only when the dog is under voice control of the owner. Retractable leashes are prohibited in Common Areas.
sections.plain_language: Dogs must be on a leash (6 feet max) whenever outside your property. The only exception is the dog park, where dogs can be off-leash if they listen to your commands. No retractable leashes in common areas.

sections.title: Pets - Cats and Other Pets
sections.content: Cats must be kept indoors or within the owner's enclosed Lot. Free-roaming cats are prohibited. Other common household pets including birds, fish, hamsters, guinea pigs, rabbits, and non-venomous reptiles are permitted when kept indoors. Exotic pets including but not limited to snakes over six (6) feet, venomous reptiles, primates, large cats, bears, and other wildlife are prohibited.
sections.plain_language: Cats must stay inside your home or fenced yard—no outdoor roaming. Small pets like birds, fish, hamsters, guinea pigs, rabbits, and small reptiles are fine indoors. No exotic pets like large snakes, venomous animals, monkeys, or wild animals.

sections.title: Pets - Service and Assistance Animals
sections.content: Service animals and emotional support animals with proper documentation are exempt from breed and weight restrictions. Owners must provide documentation from a licensed healthcare provider for emotional support animals or certification for service animals. The Association reserves the right to require removal of any animal, regardless of status, that poses a direct threat to the health or safety of others. Reasonable accommodation requests should be submitted to the management office.
sections.plain_language: Service animals and emotional support animals with proper documentation are exempt from breed and weight rules. Provide documentation from your doctor for ESAs or service animal certification. Even with documentation, an animal that's dangerous to others may need to be removed.

sections.title: Insurance Requirements
sections.content: Each Owner shall maintain homeowner's insurance with coverage of at least the full replacement cost of all improvements on their Lot. Owners shall also maintain personal liability coverage of at least three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000). Upon request, Owners must provide the Association with evidence of current insurance coverage. Owners are encouraged to maintain coverage for assessment liability in the event of a Common Area claim.
sections.plain_language: You must have homeowner's insurance covering full replacement cost of your home, plus at least $300,000 in liability coverage. The HOA can ask to see proof of insurance.

sections.title: Enforcement and Violations - Process
sections.content: Violations of these CC&Rs or the community Rules and Regulations shall be addressed as follows: (a) First violation: written warning sent by mail and email detailing the violation and required corrective action; (b) Second violation of the same provision within twelve (12) months: fine of fifty dollars ($50); (c) Third violation within twelve (12) months: fine of one hundred dollars ($100); (d) Subsequent violations: fine of two hundred dollars ($200) each and potential legal action. Owners shall have fourteen (14) days from receipt of a fine notice to cure the violation or request a hearing before the Board. Continuing violations may be assessed daily fines after proper notice.
sections.plain_language: Violation process: 1st offense = warning letter, 2nd offense (same issue within 12 months) = $50 fine, 3rd offense = $100 fine, after that = $200 per violation plus possible legal action. You have 14 days to fix the problem or request a hearing.

sections.title: Enforcement and Violations - Appeal Process
sections.content: Any Owner who receives a fine notice may appeal by submitting a written request for a hearing to the Board of Directors within fourteen (14) days of the fine notice date. The Board shall schedule a hearing within thirty (30) days of receiving the appeal request. At the hearing, the Owner may present evidence and witnesses. The Board shall render a written decision within fourteen (14) days of the hearing. The Board's decision shall be final and binding.
sections.plain_language: If you get a fine, you can appeal by requesting a hearing in writing within 14 days. The Board will hold a hearing within 30 days where you can present your case. They'll give you a written decision within 14 days after the hearing.

sections.title: Quiet Hours and Noise
sections.content: Quiet hours are in effect during the following times: Sunday through Thursday from 10:00 PM to 7:00 AM; Friday and Saturday from 11:00 PM to 8:00 AM. During quiet hours, residents shall refrain from activities that create noise audible from neighboring Lots or Common Areas, including but not limited to: loud music or television, parties, power tools, lawn equipment, and loud conversations outdoors. Construction and renovation work is permitted only between 8:00 AM and 6:00 PM Monday through Friday, and 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM on Saturdays. No construction work is permitted on Sundays or federal holidays.
sections.plain_language: Keep noise down during quiet hours: 10 PM - 7 AM on weeknights, 11 PM - 8 AM on weekends. Construction work: Mon-Fri 8 AM - 6 PM, Saturdays 9 AM - 5 PM, none on Sundays or holidays.

sections.title: Trash and Recycling
sections.content: Trash and recycling containers shall be stored within the garage or behind screening not visible from the street except during designated collection periods. Containers may be placed at the curb no earlier than 5:00 PM the evening before scheduled collection and must be returned to storage by 9:00 PM on collection day. Bulk items and large appliances require special pickup—contact the waste management company to schedule. Hazardous materials must be disposed of at designated county facilities. Dumping of any materials in Common Areas is prohibited.
sections.plain_language: Keep trash cans in your garage or hidden from view except on collection days. Put cans out no earlier than 5 PM the night before pickup and bring them back in by 9 PM on pickup day. Call for bulk item pickup. Don't dump anything in common areas.

sections.title: Garage Sales and Moving Sales
sections.content: Garage sales, yard sales, and moving sales are permitted subject to the following restrictions: (a) maximum of two (2) sales per household per calendar year; (b) sales may be conducted only on Saturdays and Sundays between 8:00 AM and 4:00 PM; (c) all items must be displayed within the Lot boundaries—no items in streets, sidewalks, or Common Areas; (d) all signs must be removed immediately after the sale; (e) residents must notify the management office at least three (3) days in advance of any sale.
sections.plain_language: You can have 2 garage sales per year, on weekends only from 8 AM - 4 PM. Keep everything on your property, remove signs after, and let the office know 3 days ahead.

sections.title: Signs and Flags
sections.content: Signs are generally prohibited except: (a) one (1) professional 'For Sale' or 'For Rent' sign not exceeding eighteen (18) inches by twenty-four (24) inches; (b) one (1) security system sign; (c) political signs during election season, not more than forty-five (45) days before an election and removed within seven (7) days after; (d) temporary event signs (garage sale, open house) removed within 24 hours of event. The American flag and official state flag may be displayed on a pole attached to the dwelling not exceeding six (6) feet in length. Flags must be maintained in good condition. No flags with commercial advertising or offensive content.
sections.plain_language: Limited signs allowed: one For Sale/Rent sign (18"x24" max), one security sign, political signs near elections (45 days before, remove within 7 days after). American and state flags OK on a pole up to 6 feet. No advertising flags.

sections.title: Pool Rules
sections.content: The community pool is open from Memorial Day weekend through Labor Day, 6:00 AM to 10:00 PM daily. Pool rules include: (a) residents must have valid access card or be accompanied by cardholder; (b) maximum of four (4) guests per household; (c) children under fourteen (14) years of age must be accompanied by an adult at all times; (d) no glass containers in the pool area; (e) no diving in the shallow end; (f) no running on the pool deck; (g) appropriate swimwear required—no cutoffs or street clothes; (h) no alcohol in the pool area unless at an approved community event; (i) pool furniture may not be reserved; (j) no pets in the pool area. Violation of pool rules may result in suspension of pool privileges.
sections.plain_language: Pool is open Memorial Day to Labor Day, 6 AM - 10 PM. Bring your access card, max 4 guests, kids under 14 need adult supervision. No glass, no diving in shallow end, no running, proper swimwear required, no alcohol (except at approved events), no saving chairs, no pets.

sections.title: Fitness Center Rules
sections.content: The fitness center is available to residents twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week with valid access card. Rules include: (a) guests under eighteen (18) are not permitted; (b) appropriate athletic attire and closed-toe athletic shoes required; (c) users must wipe down equipment after use; (d) maximum thirty (30) minutes on cardio equipment when others are waiting; (e) no personal trainers conducting paid sessions; (f) the Association is not responsible for injuries—use equipment at your own risk; (g) report equipment malfunctions to management immediately.
sections.plain_language: Fitness center is open 24/7 with your access card. Must be 18+, wear workout clothes and athletic shoes, wipe equipment after use, limit cardio to 30 min if others are waiting. No paid personal training sessions allowed. Use at your own risk.

sections.title: Clubhouse Reservations
sections.content: The clubhouse community room may be reserved by residents for private events. Reservations require: (a) submission of reservation form at least fourteen (14) days in advance; (b) non-refundable reservation fee of seventy-five dollars ($75); (c) refundable security deposit of two hundred fifty dollars ($250); (d) maximum occupancy of seventy-five (75) persons; (e) events must conclude by 11:00 PM; (f) resident host must be present throughout the event; (g) cleaning and restoration of the room to original condition. The Association reserves the right to deny reservations that may disturb residents or damage facilities.
sections.plain_language: Reserve the clubhouse at least 14 days ahead. Costs: $75 reservation fee (non-refundable) plus $250 deposit (refundable if no damage). Max 75 people, must end by 11 PM, you must be there the whole time, and clean up after.

sections.title: Dog Park Rules
sections.content: The dog park is open from dawn to dusk daily. Rules include: (a) dogs must have current vaccinations and wear visible tags; (b) owners must remain in the park and supervise their dogs at all times; (c) aggressive dogs must be removed immediately; (d) owners must clean up after their dogs; (e) maximum two (2) dogs per handler; (f) puppies under four (4) months and female dogs in heat are not permitted; (g) no food or treats in the off-leash area; (h) children under twelve (12) must be accompanied by an adult.
sections.plain_language: Dog park is open dawn to dusk. Dogs need current vaccines and visible tags. You must stay and supervise. Clean up after your dog. Max 2 dogs per person. No puppies under 4 months, no dogs in heat, no food/treats in the off-leash area. Kids under 12 need an adult.

sections.title: Guest Policy
sections.content: Residents are responsible for the conduct of their guests at all times. Guests must be accompanied by a resident when using community amenities. Long-term guests staying more than fourteen (14) consecutive days or more than thirty (30) days in any calendar year must be registered with the management office. Unauthorized occupants may be considered a violation of the rental restrictions.
sections.plain_language: You're responsible for your guests' behavior. Guests need a resident with them to use amenities. If someone stays more than 14 days straight or 30 days total in a year, register them with the office.

sections.title: Move-In/Move-Out Procedures
sections.content: All move-in and move-out activities must be scheduled with the management office at least seventy-two (72) hours in advance. Move-in fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150) is required. Moving activities are permitted Monday through Saturday, 8:00 AM to 6:00 PM only—no Sunday or holiday moves. Elevator pads must be used in buildings with elevators. Moving trucks may not block fire lanes or other residents' access. Residents are responsible for any damage to Common Areas during moving.
sections.plain_language: Schedule your move 72 hours ahead. There's a $150 move-in fee. Moving allowed Mon-Sat, 8 AM - 6 PM only (no Sundays/holidays). Use elevator pads where required. Don't block fire lanes. You pay for any damage to common areas.

sections.title: Solicitation and Canvassing
sections.content: Door-to-door solicitation and canvassing by non-residents is prohibited. Residents may not solicit other residents for commercial purposes. Distribution of commercial flyers, advertisements, or promotional materials in Common Areas or on vehicles is prohibited. Political candidates and their representatives may canvass during election periods in compliance with applicable law.
sections.plain_language: No door-to-door sales from non-residents. Residents can't sell to other residents. No putting flyers on cars or in common areas. Political campaigning is allowed during election season.

sections.title: Common Area Use
sections.content: Common Areas are for the use and enjoyment of all residents. The following activities are prohibited in Common Areas: (a) ball playing, skateboarding, rollerblading, or similar activities except in designated areas; (b) barbecuing or open flames except in designated picnic areas; (c) consumption of alcohol except at approved community events or designated areas; (d) littering; (e) feeding wildlife; (f) damage to landscaping, trees, or community property; (g) blocking sidewalks, pathways, or fire lanes; (h) leaving personal property unattended.
sections.plain_language: Common areas are for everyone. No ball playing, skateboarding, etc. except in designated spots. BBQ only in picnic areas. No alcohol except at approved events. Don't litter, feed wildlife, damage plants, block walkways, or leave stuff unattended.

sections.title: Security and Access
sections.content: Access cards are required for entry through community gates and use of amenities. Each household is issued two (2) access cards at no charge. Additional cards may be purchased for twenty-five dollars ($25) each. Lost or stolen cards must be reported immediately to the management office for deactivation. Tailgating (allowing non-cardholders to enter through gates) is prohibited. Do not prop gates open. Report suspicious activity to security or local police.
sections.plain_language: You get 2 free access cards for gates and amenities. Extra cards cost $25. Report lost cards immediately so they can be deactivated. Don't let people follow you through gates and don't prop gates open.

sections.title: Exterior Storage and Appearance
sections.content: No items shall be stored on balconies, patios, or in yards that are visible from neighboring properties or Common Areas except: (a) patio furniture designed for outdoor use; (b) barbecue grills; (c) potted plants in appropriate containers; (d) seasonal furniture stored neatly. Specifically prohibited: indoor furniture, appliances, boxes, building materials, auto parts, bicycles (except in approved racks), and tarps or covers over stored items. Window-mounted air conditioning units are prohibited. Window treatments visible from outside must be white, off-white, or neutral in color.
sections.plain_language: Keep visible outdoor areas neat. OK to have: patio furniture, grills, potted plants. Not OK: indoor furniture outside, appliances, boxes, building materials, car parts, tarps over stuff, bikes (except in racks). No window AC units. Window coverings facing outside must be white or neutral.

documents.title: Bylaws of Oakwood Commons Homeowners Association

sections.title: Board of Directors
sections.content: The Association shall be governed by a Board of Directors consisting of five (5) members elected by the membership. Directors serve two-year staggered terms. The Board shall meet at least monthly and maintain minutes of all meetings. Special meetings may be called by the President or any three (3) Directors.
sections.plain_language: The HOA is run by a 5-member Board elected by homeowners. Directors serve 2-year terms. The Board meets at least once a month.

sections.title: Voting and Elections
sections.content: Each Lot is entitled to one (1) vote on all matters submitted to a vote of the membership. Elections are held at the annual meeting. Candidates must be Owners in good standing. Absentee voting by proxy or written ballot is permitted. A quorum of twenty percent (20%) of eligible voters is required for any membership vote.
sections.plain_language: Each home gets one vote. Elections happen at the annual meeting. You can vote by proxy or mail-in ballot if you can't attend. At least 20% of homeowners need to participate for a vote to count.

sections.title: Annual Meeting
sections.content: The annual meeting of the membership shall be held in January of each year at a time and place determined by the Board. Notice of the annual meeting shall be provided at least thirty (30) days in advance. The agenda shall include election of Directors, presentation of annual budget, and such other business as may properly come before the meeting.
sections.plain_language: The annual homeowner meeting is in January. You'll get 30 days' notice. They'll elect board members, present the budget, and discuss other HOA business.

sections.title: Assessments and Dues
sections.content: The Board shall establish annual assessments (dues) to fund the operation of the Association. Assessments are due on the first day of each month. A late fee of twenty-five dollars ($25) shall be assessed for payments received more than fifteen (15) days past due. Accounts more than sixty (60) days past due may be subject to collection proceedings and lien against the property.
sections.plain_language: HOA dues are due on the 1st of each month. If you're more than 15 days late, there's a $25 late fee. After 60 days late, they can start collections and put a lien on your home.

sections.title: Special Assessments
sections.content: Special assessments for capital improvements or unexpected expenses exceeding five percent (5%) of the annual budget require approval by a majority vote of the membership. The Board may levy special assessments up to five percent (5%) of the annual budget without member approval for emergency repairs.
sections.plain_language: Big special charges (over 5% of the budget) need homeowner vote approval. The Board can charge up to 5% of the budget for emergencies without a vote.
